PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Cardiac amyloidosis is a condition in which a substance called amyloid builds up in the heart. 2. Amyloid is an abnormal protein that is produced in bone marrow and can be deposited in various organs of the body. 3. Cardiac amyloidosis can cause problems with the heart's ability to pump blood. 4. The most common cause of cardiac amyloidosis is a condition called AL amyloidosis. 5. AL stands for primary amyloidosis light chain. 6. In AL amyloidosis, there is an excess of production of light chains of antibodies. 7. These light chains can build up in organs of the body, including the heart. 8. Cardiac amyloidosis can lead to heart failure, an irregular heartbeat, or sudden death. 9. The symptoms of cardiac amyloidosis can vary from person to person. 10. Diagnosis of cardiac amyloidosis is based on a physical exam, lab tests, and imaging tests. 11. Treatment of cardiac amyloidosis is aimed at slowing down the build-up of amyloid and reducing the workload of the heart. 12. Treatment may include medicines, chemotherapy, and a specialized diet. 13. In some cases, a heart transplant may be an option.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Migraine is a very complex disorder and there are many types and subtypes of migraine.  There are also many different treatments for migraine.  There is a lot of research on the different types of migraine and the different treatments that work for each type.  You should talk to your daughters doctors about what type of migraine she has and what treatments might work best for her.  There are treatments that work for most types of migraine.  There are also treatments that work for only one or two types of migraine.  It is important to know exactly what type of migraine your daughter has before trying to decide on a treatment.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Yes, there are studies that have investigated which migraine treatments are most effective for specific migraine conditions. 2. For example, one study found that people with migraine associated with aura had the best response to propranolol, while those with non-aura migraine responded best to propranolol or one of the triptans. Another study found that people whose migraines were triggered by lifestyle factors (e.g., lack of sleep, missed meals, caffeine withdrawal) responded best to preventive therapy, while those whose migraines were not triggered by lifestyle factors responded best to acute therapy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Yes.  Researchers have studied how well different treatments work for people with different types of migraines.  For example, they have studied how well triptans, ergotamine drugs, and analgesics work for people with migraine with aura, migraine without aura, and chronic migraine.  They have also studied how well preventive medicines work for people with migraine.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Summary Migraine is a common, debilitating disorder that affects a substantial proportion of the population. 2. The pathophysiology of migraine is not fully understood, but it is clear that the disorder is more than simply a problem with vascular tone. 3. The trigeminal system plays a key role in migraine, but the exact mechanism by which migraine headache pain is generated remains elusive. 4. The pharmacologic treatment of migraine can be approached in a stepwise fashion, starting with simple analgesics and progressing to more potent but potentially addictive medications as necessary. 5. The use of botulinum toxin is increasing as a treatment for migraine, but its ultimate role remains uncertain. 6. Identification of specific subtypes of migraine may allow for more targeted therapy in the future.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Yes, several studies have attempted to categorize migraine treatments by their effectiveness against specific migraine subtypes. 2) However, the results of these studies have been inconsistent, making it difficult to draw firm conclusions about the relative effectiveness of treatments for different migraine subtypes.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) Yes, there is scientific evidence that links specific migraine treatments to their effectiveness against distinct migraine conditions. 2) The scientific evidence shows that: a) Triptans are the most effective treatments for migraine with aura; b) Triptans and ergotamine are the most effective treatments for migraine without aura; c) Triptans are the most effective treatments for migraine with typical aura; d) Triptans and ergotamine are the most effective treatments for cluster headache; e) Sumatriptan is the most effective treatment for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia associated with migraine; f) There is insufficient evidence to determine the relative efficacy of treatments for cranial neuralgias and other facial pain syndromes associated with migraine; g) There is insufficient evidence to determine the relative efficacy of treatments for chronic migraine.

Researchers also are investigating the role of diet, smoking, ultraviolet (UV) light, and other environmental factors in the development of AMD. Several clinical trials are underway to test new treatments for AMD. For example, one study is testing whether high-dose supplements of antioxidants (vitamin C, vitamin E, and beta-carotene) can slow the progression of AMD. Another study is testing whether a combination of high-dose antioxidants and light-sensitive molecules (photosensitizers) can slow the progression of dry AMD. Other studies are testing drugs that may slow the progression of wet AMD. To locate current clinical trials on AMD, visit the ClinicalTrials.gov Web site at http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. NIH's National Library of Medicine also has a Web site--http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/--to search for studies on AMD and other diseases. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism—the way the body uses energy—and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism--the way the body uses energy. It also helps control the way children grow and develop. 3. Hypothyroidism can be caused by problems with the thyroid gland or by problems with the pituitary gland, which makes thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH tells the thyroid gland how much thyroid hormone to make. 4. Hypothyroidism can be passed down through families (inherited). It can also be caused by certain medicines, radiation treatment, and problems with the thyroid gland. 5. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and depression. A child with this condition may be slower to develop and may have feeding problems as a baby. 6. The condition may be diagnosed with a blood test that measures thyroid hormone levels. Treatment involves taking a pill every day that contains the correct amount of thyroid hormone.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. The most common cause of hypothyroidism is an autoimmune disorder called Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Hashimoto's thyroiditis occurs when the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. 3. Other causes of hypothyroidism include:   - Certain medications, such as lithium and amiodarone  - Radiation treatment of the thyroid  - Some genetic diseases  - Problems with the thyroid gland that are present at birth  - Thyroid surgery  - Thyroiditis, which is inflammation of the thyroid  - Too much or too little iodine in the diet  - Very high or very low levels of magnesium or zinc in the body  - Very high levels of iron in the body  - Other diseases
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. Hypothyroidism can be caused by problems with the thyroid gland itself, or it can be caused by problems in the pituitary gland, which makes thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH tells the thyroid gland how much thyroid hormone to make. 4. Common causes of hypothyroidism include Hashimoto's disease, thyroiditis (inflammation of the thyroid), thyroid surgery, radiation treatment of the thyroid, and certain medicines. 5. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and depression. 6. Other symptoms include: - Difficulty concentrating - Dry hair - Dry skin - Feeling cold - Forgetfulness - Hoarse voice - Irritability - Puffy face - Puffy hands and feet - Swelling of the legs or face - Weight loss 7. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs.  Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid.  Hypothyroidism is a common problem. It affects about 4.6 percent of women and 1.6 percent of men.  Hypothyroidism is more common in people over age 50.  Hypothyroidism is often caused by Hashimoto's disease, which is an autoimmune disorder.  Hashimoto's disease occurs when the immune system attacks the thyroid gland.  Other causes of hypothyroidism include:  - An injury to the thyroid gland  - Certain medicines  - Radioactive iodine used to treat an overactive thyroid gland  - Some medicines used to treat heart disease and depression  - Viral infections  - Pregnancy  - Iodine deficiency  - Genetic disorders  - Congenital hypothyroidism (a condition present at birth)  - Hypopituitarism (a condition in which the pituitary gland does not make enough TSH, the hormone that stimulates the thyroid gland)  - Diabetes  - Down syndrome  - Celiac disease  - Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis  - Amyloidosis  - Sarcoidosis  - Riedel's thyroiditis  - Overactive or toxic thyroid gland

Treatment for hypothyroidism is usually lifelong. The goal of treatment is to raise the thyroid hormone levels to a normal range. 22. People with hypothyroidism usually take a pill every day to replace or replace thyroid hormone. 23. Most people need to take the medicine for life. 24. Other causes include inflammatory bowel disease, infections, or trauma.6. Symptoms include rectal pain during defecation, an itchy anus, the sensation of incomplete evacuation, and mucus discharge.7. Diagnosis is by inspection of the anal canal.8. Treatment is generally conservative, with stool softeners and increased fiber intake.9. Surgery is usually only required in cases of chronic fissures or when conservative treatment fails.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Early inflammatory arthritis (EIA) is defined as clinically evident synovial inflammation (swelling, effusion, or warmth of a joint) of <6 months duration that is not explained by another disease. 2. Classical rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is diagnosed if 1 major and 2 minor criteria are present. 3. Diagnostic criteria for rheumatoid arthritis according to the 1987 revised criteria of the American Rheumatism Association: a. Morning stiffness (in and around joints, lasting 1 h) b. Arthritis (swelling) of 3 or more joint areas c. Arthritis of hand joints (wrists, MCP, PIP) d. Symmetric arthritis e. Rheumatoid nodules f. Serum rheumatoid factor (RF) g. Radiographic changes (erosions and/or peri-articular osteopenia in hand and/or wrist joints) h. Normal acute phase reactants (erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein) i. Long-standing (chronic) synovitis (>6 months) of 1 or more joint areas.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3:
1998 words

Introduction: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the joints, often resulting in joint destruction and deformity. The onset of RA is typically insidious, with symptoms presenting over months to years.

Methods: A literature search was conducted using PubMed and Ovid to identify relevant articles.

Results: The initial symptoms of RA are often subtle and may consist of fatigue, low-grade fever, and joint pain. The joint pain is typically symmetric and often involves the small joints of the hands and feet. Morning stiffness and joint swelling may be present, particularly in the hands and wrists. Over time, joint damage may occur, resulting in joint deformities and disability.

Conclusion: Health care professionals should be aware of the subtle signs and symptoms of RA to ensure that a timely diagnosis can be made so that appropriate treatment can be started to help prevent joint damage and disability.

### Answer: yes

The risk of developing RA is higher if a person has certain genetic markers, such as the HLA-DR4 subtype. 6. People who have other diseases that involve the immune system, such as Sjogren's syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), also have an increased risk of developing RA. 7. There is no cure for RA. Treatment can relieve symptoms and slow the progress of the disease.

People with OI may experience other symptoms, such as hearing loss or dental abnormalities.  OI is most often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.  This means one copy of the altered gene in each parent can cause the disorder.  In most cases, a person with OI inherits the disorder from one affected parent.  People with OI have a 50% chance of passing it on with each pregnancy.  There is also a small chance of inheriting OI in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each parent must be altered for a person to be affected.  In this case, both parents who have one copy of the gene mutation have one in two chance of having a child with OI with each pregnancy.  A small number of cases of OI are the result of a new gene mutation.  These cases are called sporadic and do not follow a pattern of inheritance.  The severity of OI varies greatly from person to person.  Some people have mild symptoms while others have more severe symptoms.  A severe form of OI can result in death in the womb or shortly after birth.  People with milder forms of OI may not be diagnosed until later in life when they break a bone or develop other signs of the disorder. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder that results in fragile, easily broken bones. It is one of a group of disorders known as osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta is also known as brittle bone disease, or Lobstein syndrome when it is passed from parent to child.  People with OI are born with defective connective tissue, or without the ability to make it. This means their bones, teeth, and skin are very fragile. A baby with OI may break bones in the womb or may be born with broken bones.  OI is a genetic disorder. It is usually caused by a mutation in one of two genes, COLLA1 and COLLA2, which are responsible for making type I collagen. Type I collagen is a protein that makes up more than 90% of the collagen in our bodies. It is found in our skin, bones, teeth, tendons, and ligaments. Twenty-two patients with BMS (10 males, 12 females; mean age 51.5 years; range 25-75 years) were enrolled in this double-blind, placebo-controlled study. 5. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either a single dose of granisetron 20 mg or placebo. 6. The primary efficacy variable was the change from baseline in the intensity of burning sensations at 15 min post-dose, measured using a visual analog scale (VAS). 7. The mean intensity of burning sensations at baseline was 6.9 (standard deviation (SD) 1.9) on a 10-cm VAS. Following granisetron administration, the mean intensity was reduced to 5.6 (SD 2.1) (P = 0.003) compared with placebo, where the mean intensity was 7.1 (SD 2.0) (P = 0.048). 8. A significant treatment effect was also observed for the mean change from baseline in the intensity of burning sensations at 30 min (P = 0.003) and 45 min (P = 0.014) post-dose. 9. Granisetron produced a rapid and statistically significant reduction in the intensity of burning sensations in patients with BMS. 10. Further studies are warranted to investigate the potential of 5-HT3 antagonists as a treatment for BMS.

Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.  If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately:    suicidal thoughts, increased anxiety, hostility, agitation, impulsivity, akathisia (restlessness), tremor, muscle twitching, dilated pupils, excessive urination, heart palpitations, or jitteriness.  Never abruptly stop taking Wellbutrin HCL XL, or any antidepressant, unless directed to do so by your doctor.  Always talk to your doctor about stopping treatment. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder that affects fat and vitamin absorption. 2. The condition is caused by a defect in the Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein (MTTP) gene. 3. The MTTP gene provides instructions for making a protein that is essential for the formation and normal function of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. 4. Without this protein, the body is unable to make chylomicrons, VLDL, or LDL. 5. As a result, the body is unable to absorb and use dietary fat and fat-soluble vitamins. 6. Symptoms of abetalipoproteinemia include: failure to thrive despite a good appetite, diarrhea, steatorrhea, retinitis pigmentosa, acanthocytosis, and fat malabsorption. 7. Treatment includes: a low-fat diet, medium-chain triglycerides, vitamin supplements, and specialized nutrition education. 8. Genetic testing can be used to diagnose abetalipoproteinemia, but it is not always necessary. 9. A detailed clinical exam, medical history, and blood tests are usually enough to make a diagnosis.

Myotonic dystrophy can affect the heart, endocrine system, and other organs in addition to the skeletal muscles. 6. Oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy (OPMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive weakness and wasting (atrophy) of the muscles in the eyes and throat. 7. Congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) is a group of disorders characterized by muscle weakness and wasting (atrophy) that is present at birth (congenital).

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.  The most common course of the disease is the relapsing-remitting subtype, which is characterized by unpredictable acute attacks (relapses) followed by periods of relative remission with no new signs of disease activity (remissions).  The other type of MS is progressive.  There is no cure for MS, and the treatment depends on the course of the disease.  In relapsing-remitting MS, the goal of treatment is to prevent relapses, and the disease-modifying agents are generally effective in achieving this goal.  Treatment for acute attack is short-term high-dose corticosteroids.  In progressive MS, treatment is aimed at reducing the progression of disability and includes disease-modifying agents and symptomatic treatment.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss. The other type of MS is progressive.  It is characterized by a steady neurologic decline from disease onset.  It is usually associated with a poorer prognosis than relapsing-remitting MS.  The prognosis for any individual with MS is difficult to predict.  Factors that may correlate with a more favorable prognosis include female sex, onset prior to age 40, optic neuritis as the initial manifestation, and a relapsing-remitting course.  Factors associated with a less favorable prognosis include male sex, onset after age 40, progressive course, and poor response to initial therapy.  In terms of treatment, there are several medications that have been approved for MS.  These include four different forms of interferon beta, glatiramer acetate, and two different oral agents- fingolimod and teriflunomide.  These medications have been shown to reduce the frequency of attacks and slow the progression of disability.  Other medications that have been used to treat MS include methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, and mitoxantrone.  These medications are reserved for patients who do not respond to the more conventional therapies.  Unfortunately, none of the medications have been shown to provide a cure for MS.  In terms of future treatments, there are several medications currently being studied in clinical trials.  These include anti-LINGO-1, anti-LINGO-1 (BIIB018), anti-MAG (LIT), anti-PDPN, and several others.  It is unclear what the exact role of these medications will be and if any of them will provide a cure for MS.  It is hoped that one of the current medications or future medications will provide a cure for MS

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by the destruction of myelin, the fatty covering that insulates nerve fibers. The nerve damage caused by MS can be irreversible. Common symptoms include visual disturbances, fatigue, difficulty walking, weakness or numbness, and problems with coordination or balance. Individuals have varying courses of the disease, and it is often marked by relapses and remissions.  The cause of MS is unknown, but research suggests that it results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. MS is most common in temperate climates, and prevalence increases the further away from the equator. MS is twice as common in women as in men, and prevalence among family members of people with MS is higher than in the general population.  The diagnosis of MS is based on a combination of signs, symptoms, examination findings, and tests. MRI scans can help confirm the diagnosis.  Treatment for MS is typically with disease-modifying drugs which reduce the frequency and severity of relapses, and with symptomatic drugs which help to treat the disease's manifestations.  The prognosis of MS is variable. The disease is usually slowly progressive, but the course can be much more rapid. Life expectancy is reduced, but the average age of death is not reduced significantly.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a mental disorder that can develop after a person is exposed to a traumatic event, such as sexual assault, warfare, traffic collisions, or other threats on a person's life. Symptoms may include disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the events, mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues, attempts to avoid trauma-related cues, alterations in how a person thinks and feels, and an increase in the fight-or-flight response. These symptoms last for more than a month after the event. Young children are less likely to show distress, but instead may express their memories through play.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection that affects the small intestine and other parts of the body. Without treatment, the disease can be fatal. It can cause diarrhea, weight loss, joint pain, and neurological problems. It is most common in middle-aged white men.  Whipple's disease is caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. The bacteria grow in the small intestine and can spread to other parts of the body, such as the joints, brain, and nerves.  The goal of treatment is to kill the bacteria and relieve symptoms. Antibiotics are the main treatment. People usually take a combination of two antibiotics for 1 to 2 years.  A person may need to be hospitalized for treatment at first. Health care providers may give IV (intravenous) fluids to prevent dehydration, and anti-inflammatory medicines to relieve joint pain.  Recurrent symptoms may occur if the course of antibiotics is not completed, or if the disease is not fully treated. Without treatment, the disease can be fatal.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 2012 nih.gov/pubmed/8986162?related=pubmed&ei=_F8hU8n8F4K0yASj2YGYCw&bvm=bv.44134254,d.bWO&um=1&ie=UTF-8&q=whipple%27s+disease&output=rss" class="source-link" title="Whipple's Disease: A Review" rel="nofollow">Whipple's Disease: A Review. Author: Cohen P. Source: Gastroenterology Review/1992 - 1993; 6 (3): 269-275. Abstract: Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. It typically affects middle-aged Caucasian men. The clinical presentation is often as a multi-system disease, with the most common symptoms being joint pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Malabsorption is present in the majority of patients. Affected organs include the small intestine, joints, central nervous system, and the cardiovascular system. The disease may be fatal if untreated. Patients with Whipple's disease may have a characteristic facial appearance, with a "wasted" appearance and "sunken" eyes. The disease is often fatal if untreated, with a median survival of 12 months from the time of diagnosis. The disease is best diagnosed by a small intestinal biopsy. The biopsy sample must be evaluated by a pathologist with expertise in this disease, as the histopathology may be subtle. The treatment of choice is double-strength trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The majority of patients will have a dramatic and complete response to this therapy.

Intractable lesions may be treated by laser (CO2 or erbium-YAG) "resurfacing" or dermabrasion.

B) Other drugs: If the blood pressure goal is not achieved with low-dose thiazide diuretic monotherapy, combination therapy with a calcium channel blocker, an ACE inhibitor, or a beta blocker should be initiated. D) Special populations: In patients with heart failure, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB should be used as the first-line antihypertensive drug. In patients with hypertension and chronic kidney disease, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB should be used if there is no contraindication. In patients with diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB should be used as the first-line antihypertensive drug. In African Americans, a thiazide diuretic or a calcium channel blocker is recommended as the first-line antihypertensive drug.

Both are due to multiple factors beyond the control of the individual. 2)Yes, putting a tax on junk food will reduce the amount of obese people. The tax will make healthy food more affordable compared to junk food. 3)Prevent obesity by encouraging healthy eating habits in childhood, providing healthy food in schools, and providing healthy food in hospitals and other institutions. 4)Benefits of exercise include improved cardiovascular health, improved weight control, improved mood, improved sleep, and reduced risk of depression, heart attack, stroke, diabetes, and some cancers. 5)The government should be more involved in helping to stop obesity by providing better food choices in schools, providing better access to healthy foods in low-income neighborhoods, and taxing unhealthy foods. 6)The number one thing to eat less of is added sugars. Added sugars are in soft drinks, fruit drinks, cakes, cookies, candy, and many other processed foods.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1) The rise of obesity is due to a combination of factors including the increased availability of cheap, high-calorie food and the decreased physical activity levels of many Americans. 2) A junk food tax could be effective in reducing obesity rates, but it would need to be substantial enough to make a difference. 3) Preventative strategies for obesity include promoting healthy diet and exercise habits in children, providing easy access to healthy foods, and educating people about the dangers of obesity. 4) The advantages of engaging in 30 minutes of daily exercise and a healthy diet include improved physical fitness, weight loss, and a reduced risk of developing obesity-related diseases such as diabetes and heart disease. 5) The government should play a significant role in combating obesity by promoting healthy lifestyles, providing educational programs, and supporting research into the causes and treatment of obesity. 6) The most critical dietary component to limit or eliminate to combat obesity is likely high-calorie, high-fat foods such as fast foods and sweets.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1) The primary causes of obesity are the environmental factors that promote excessive food consumption and discourage physical activity. 2) No, I do not think that imposing a tax on unhealthy foods will lead to a decrease in obesity cases. The tax would have to be very high to affect behavior, and even then, it would be difficult to enforce. 3) Obesity can be prevented by encouraging healthy eating habits and physical activity at an early age. Parents and teachers can model healthy behaviors and encourage children to make healthy food choices. Schools can offer nutritious meals and opportunities for physical activity. 4) A balanced diet and 30 minutes of exercise each day provide many benefits, including weight control, improved cardiovascular health, and reduced risk of diabetes, heart disease, and some cancers. 5) Yes, the government should take a more active role in addressing the obesity epidemic. Government policies could influence food production, distribution, and marketing; the built environment; and health care. 6) We should prioritize reducing our intake of added sugars, such as those found in soft drinks, sports drinks, and processed foods.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1) The factors that contribute most to the prevalence of obesity are the availability of cheap, high-calorie food and the lack of exercise. 2) A tax on junk food might be an effective strategy for reducing obesity rates because it would make these foods more expensive, thereby encouraging people to eat healthier foods. 3) To prevent obesity, people need to eat a balanced diet, exercise regularly, and get enough sleep. Parents can model healthy behaviors for their children and encourage physical activity. Schools can offer nutritious meals and opportunities for physical exercise. Communities can create safe places for people to walk and bike. 4) The advantages of regular exercise and a healthy diet include improved physical fitness, weight loss, and a reduced risk of heart disease, diabetes, and other health problems. 5) The government should be more involved in efforts to combat obesity because obesity rates have been rising rapidly and the health consequences are serious. The government can sponsor educational programs, provide better access to healthy foods, and encourage physical activity through programs like the "Walk Across America" initiative. 6) The most important dietary change we can make to reduce obesity is to eat a balanced diet that includes plenty of fruits and vegetables and limits our intake of high-calorie foods.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) The main causes of obesity are overeating and lack of physical activity. 2) Yes, a tax on unhealthy foods would help reduce obesity because it would make those foods more expensive and therefore people would be less likely to buy them. 3) Preventing obesity means eating healthy foods, exercising regularly, and avoiding overeating. 4) Exercising for 30 minutes daily and eating a healthy diet can help prevent obesity because it helps maintain a healthy weight. 5) The government should play a bigger role in addressing obesity because it is a public health problem that affects many people. 6) The food component that should be limited or avoided to reduce obesity is saturated fat, which is found in foods like fried foods, fatty meats, and full-fat dairy products.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) The growing obesity problem is due to a combination of factors including poor dietary choices, lack of exercise, genetic predisposition, and social norms. 2) Taxing junk food may be one way to reduce obesity rates, but it would be difficult to enforce and may unfairly target low-income individuals who may not have a choice but to purchase unhealthy foods due to cost and availability. 3) Preventing obesity can be done by encouraging healthy eating habits from an early age, increasing physical activity, and modeling healthy behaviors for children. 4) The advantages of regular exercise and a balanced diet include improved physical and mental health, weight loss, and decreased risk of chronic diseases such as heart disease, diabetes, and some cancers. 5) The government should take a more prominent role in combating obesity by increasing funding for research, education, and intervention programs. The government can also influence social norms, food industry regulations, and healthcare policies to promote healthy behaviors. 6) We should focus on reducing our intake of sugar-sweetened beverages, processed meats, and foods high in saturated and trans fats.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Lynch syndrome is an inherited condition that causes an increased risk of developing colon cancer and rectal cancer. 2. People with Lynch syndrome also have an increased risk of developing cancer of the stomach, small intestine, liver, gallbladder ducts, upper urinary tract, brain, skin, and prostate. 3. Women with Lynch syndrome have a high risk of developing uterine cancer (also called endometrial cancer) and ovarian cancer. 4. People with Lynch syndrome usually develop cancer at a younger age than those who do not have it. 5. Lynch syndrome is caused by a mutation in one of several genes. The most common gene that is mutated is called MLH1. The MLH1 gene makes a protein called MSH2. 6. A mutation in the MLH1 gene can also turn off the gene. 7. When this happens, there is no MSH2 protein. 8. The MSH2 protein is pa of a protein pair called a heterodimer. 9. The other protein in the heterodimer is called MSH6. 10. A mutation in the MLH1 gene can also turn off the MSH6 protein. 11. The MSH6 protein is needed to fix the mistakes that are made when DNA copies itself. 12. When the MSH6 protein is not working, DNA copies itself wrong. 13. This causes more and more new cells to have mutations. 14. These mutations can cause cells to become cancerous. 15. People with Lynch syndrome usually have one mutated copy of the MLH1 gene in the cell and one working copy. 16. The person who has one working copy of MLH1 does not have cancer. 17. The person who has one working copy of MLH1 can pass Lynch syndrome on to his or her children. 18. A person who has one nonworking copy of MLH1 does not have an increased risk of cancer. 19. A person who has two nonworking copies of MLH1 does have an increased risk of cancer. 20. The chance of passing Lynch syndrome on to your children depends on whether you have one working copy of MLH1 or two nonworking copies of MLH1.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. It is estimated that over 2 million Americans have glaucoma.  The condition often develops without noticeable symptoms and without causing pain. Vision loss usually begins in the peripheral, or side, vision. This occurs because the optic nerve is located in the periphery of the retina.  Because glaucoma is painless, it is often called "the silent thief of sight."  The goal of treatment is to prevent vision loss.  Early treatment of glaucoma can help protect your eyes against serious vision loss. Treatment usually involves prescription eyedrops and/or surgery.  The eyedrops reduce the pressure in the eye. Surgery is usually a laser procedure. It can increase the flow of natural eye fluids, which helps reduce pressure inside the eye.  With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.

The goal of glaucoma treatment is to lower eye pressure. Medicines, laser surgery, and glaucoma surgery can all lower eye pressure. 5. To keep glaucoma from getting worse, you should have regular eye exams and eye pressure checks. You should also use your glaucoma medicine exactly as prescribed.

This causes a sudden rise in pressure in the eye. 4. There are many types of glaucoma. The two main groups of glaucoma are: Open-angle glaucoma. Narrow-angle glaucoma. 5. Open-angle glaucoma is the most common type of glaucoma. It is caused by a build-up of fluid in the eye. This build-up occurs because the fluid drains too slowly from the eye. 6. Narrow-angle glaucoma is a less common form of glaucoma. It occurs in people who have a narrow entrance to the angle. This causes a sudden rise in pressure in the eye. 7. There are several risk factors for glaucoma. They include: Age. People over age 60 are at higher risk. Race. African Americans have a higher risk for glaucoma than other races. Family history. People with a family history of glaucoma are at higher risk. Increased pressure in the eye. Increased pressure in the eye is called intraocular pressure (IOP). 8. The goal of glaucoma treatment is to lower the pressure in the eye. The type of treatment depends on the type of glaucoma. It also depends on how much vision has been lost and whether the glaucoma is open-angle or narrow-angle. 9. Early glaucoma can be treated with eye drops. If the drops do not work, then laser surgery may be done. If the condition continues to get worse, then traditional glaucoma surgery may be needed.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The first thing to do is to get a complete physical examination by a surgeon. 2. The surgeon will also order additional tests such as a mammogram, ultrasound, and/or a biopsy to help determine the stage of the cancer. 3. The stage of the cancer will determine the treatment options. 4. The most common treatment for breast cancer is surgery. 5. The surgeon will remove the tumor with a margin of normal-looking tissue. 6. The amount of tissue removed will depend on the size of the tumor and whether or not the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes. 7. If the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes, the surgeon may remove some of the lymph nodes for examination. 8. The surgeon may also remove a portion of the muscle that lies under the tumor to make sure that the cancer has not spread outside the milk duct. 9. The surgery is usually done under general anesthesia. 10. The surgical procedure is called a lumpectomy if the tumor is removed with a margin of normal-looking tissue. 11. The surgical procedure is called a mastectomy if the entire breast and some of the underlying muscle are removed. 12. If the cancer is large or has spread to nearby lymph nodes, the surgeon may recommend a procedure called a sentinel lymph node biopsy. 13. In this procedure, the surgeon injects blue dye and/or a radioactive substance near the tumor. 14. A femoral hernia occurs when a portion of the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal (located below the inguinal ligament at the junction of the thigh and the pelvis).10. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 12 years ago I was bitten by tick while deer hunting. The bite area contained the ring as described in Lyme Disease symptoms. Also, usually prior to, and during these symptoms I have a reddish-pink welt appear at the site of the bite on my groin. Can you offer any enlightment on my condition? Lyme disease is caused by a bacteria called Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted through the bite of a tick. The symptoms of Lyme disease include fever, headache, fatigue, body aches, joint pain, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. The skin rash usually expands slowly over a period of days to weeks, and it typically develops at the site of the tick bite. The rash is usually red, and it may be warm or itchy. Other symptoms of Lyme disease include meningitis, heart disease, and nervous system abnormalities. The diagnosis of Lyme disease is usually based on symptoms, a history of exposure to ticks, and blood tests to detect antibodies to the bacteria. Treatment with antibiotics is usually very effective, especially if begun early. Without treatment, symptoms may resolve, but recurrence of symptoms is common. I suggest you to visit your doctor for a physical examination and for blood tests. Hope this helps.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. You should know that Parkinson's disease is a degenerative disease of the brain that results in the loss of dopamine-producing brain cells. 2. The initial dose of levodopa is low and is gradually increased as the disease progresses. 5. The most common side effects of levodopa are nausea and vomiting, which can be minimized by taking the medication with food. 6. Other side effects include abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and headache. 7. Be aware that levodopa may cause an abnormal movement called dyskinesia. 8. This is a complication that may develop after several years of levodopa treatment. 9. Dyskinesia is characterized by involuntary movements of the face, arms, and legs. 10. It is usually a late complication of treatment and tends to disappear when the dose is reduced. 11. Other medications that may be used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease include dopamine agonists (such as pramipexole and ropinirole) and MAO inhibitors (such as selegiline). 12. Dopamine agonists are often used as the first line of therapy in early Parkinson's or in conjunction with levodopa in advanced disease to reduce the dose of levodopa needed. 13. MAO inhibitors are generally used as an adjunct to levodopa therapy in patients who have had a good initial response to levodopa but in whom motor control has begun to deteriorate. 14. Amantadine is an antiviral agent that has been used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. 15. Anticholinergic medications (e.g., trihexyphenidyl, benztropine) are used to help with tremors but have no effect on bradykinesia. 16. Anticholinergics are generally used only when tremors are the main or only symptom.

In patients receiving positive airway pressure therapy for obstructive sleep apnea, the central sleep apnea syndrome may resolve over time. PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). CLL is a slow-growing blood and bone marrow disease that usually occurs during or after middle age. 2. The cause of CLL is not known. It is most often found in older adults. The disease is rare in people who are younger than 35 years. 3. The disease develops slowly. It may be found through a routine blood test before symptoms begin. Symptoms of CLL may include swollen lymph nodes, tiredness, weight loss, night sweats, and fever. 4. The goal of treatment is to reduce or eliminate the cancer cells. Treatment depends on whether the cancer is in just one group of lymph nodes or many groups, or whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. 5. Treatment options include watchful waiting, chemotherapy, biological therapy, radiation therapy, and plasmapheresis (plasma exchange). 6. A type of biological therapy for CLL is a vaccine. The vaccine stimulates the immune system to attack cancer cells. Another type of biological therapy for CLL is a monoclonal antibody. This treatment attaches to cancer cells and stimulates the immune system to attack and kill the cells.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. What is Familial Mediterranean Fever?  Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes, including peritoneum, pleura, and synovial membranes).  FMF is a genetic disorder, passed down through families (inherited).  FMF is most commonly found in people of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins.  The gene for FMF is found on the short arm of chromosome 16.  What causes Familial Mediterranean Fever?  FMF is caused by a problem with a protein in the blood called pyrin.  Pyrin is responsible for regulating inflammation in the body.  People with FMF have a mutation in the pyrin protein, which causes the protein to not work properly.  This causes the body to have too much inflammation.  This inflammation is what causes the symptoms of FMF.  How is Familial Mediterranean Fever diagnosed?  There is a blood test available to check for the FMF gene.  If you are known to have the gene, and you have symptoms of FMF, then you probably have FMF.  If you do not have the gene, but have symptoms of FMF, you may have another disorder.  What are the treatments for Familial Mediterranean Fever?  There is no cure for FMF.  However, medicines can help control the inflammation and pain.  The most commonly used medicines are steroids and NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory PMC-LLaMA.  People with FMF may also need medicines to control their fever and joint pain.  What are the symptoms of Familial Mediterranean Fever?  FMF is characterized by short, severe attacks of pain and fever.  The attacks last 12 to 72 hours, and are usually accompanied by one or more of the following: - abdominal pain or cramps - diarrhea - rash - fever - joint pain or swelling - muscle pain - redness or swelling of the joints 2. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Multiple brain infarcts disease is a condition in which a person has multiple areas of damage to the brain caused by a decrease or absence of blood flow.  The areas of the brain most commonly affected by this condition are the watershed areas. These are areas of the brain that are most vulnerable to decreased blood flow because they receive blood from the carotid arteries and the vertebral arteries, and have a less robust collateral circulation than other areas of the brain.  The most common cause of multiple brain infarcts is a series of emboli that travel through the bloodstream and become lodged in the small penetrating arteries of the brain.  Other causes include atherosclerosis, which can cause stenosis of the carotid and vertebral arteries, and cardiac conditions such as atrial fibrillation that can cause clots to form in the heart and subsequently embolize to the brain.  The clinical presentation of multiple brain infarcts depends on the areas of the brain affected and the severity of the damage.  Patients may have focal neurologic deficits or more generalized impairment of brain function.  Diagnosis is made by neuroimaging studies, such as CT or MRI scans.  Treatment of multiple brain infarcts is supportive.  Patients should be treated for any underlying cardiac conditions, such as atrial fibrillation, that could be causing the infarcts.  Antiplatelet agents, such as aspirin, are often used to prevent further embolization from the heart or atherosclerotic plaques in the carotid or vertebral arteries.  In patients with recurrent emboli, or those with severe or recurrent stroke, a carotid angiogram may be performed to identify any stenosis of the carotid arteries, and endarterectomy or stenting may be considered.  In patients with severe impairment of brain function, such as from a series of large infarcts, the possibility of brain death should be considered.  In such cases, the prognosis is poor, and medical intervention is generally not appropriate.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infectious disease that affects the small intestine and other organs. It is caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. The disease is characterized by the infiltration of macrophages (a type of white blood cell) in the small intestine. The macrophages contain the bacteria and show deposits of a fibrous substance called collagen.  Whipple's disease primarily affects the small intestine and the lamina propria, a layer of tissue underneath the intestinal lining. The disease may also affect other organs, including the joints, the central nervous system, the heart, the lungs, the eyes, the skin, and the kidneys.  The symptoms of Whipple's disease may come and go. They may be mild and barely noticeable, or they may be severe and debilitating. The symptoms of Whipple's disease are the result of the bacteria damaging the intestinal villi and include diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and malabsorption of nutrients.  People with Whipple's disease also may experience joint pain, swelling, and redness; changes in vision; or difficulty thinking.  The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is based on a combination of factors, including a physical examination, blood tests, and a biopsy of the small intestine. The biopsy must be examined by a pathologist who is experienced in recognizing the signs and symptoms of Whipple's disease.  Whipple's disease is treated with antibiotics. The antibiotics most commonly used to treat this disease are tetracycline and ceftriaxone.  Without treatment, Whipple's disease is fatal. With treatment, the disease is controllable and the outlook for patients is good.

A doctor can diagnose Whipple disease by looking for specific cells in a sample of tissue from the small intestine. 7. Treatment involves antibiotics, which are usually given for a few months. 8. Without treatment, the disease can be fatal.

People with this disorder have mild to severe intellectual disability.  There is no cure for this disorder.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Yes, there are individuals with autosomal recessive primary microcephaly.  The term primary microcephaly refers to a group of disorders in which an individual's head is significantly smaller than expected due to a problem with brain growth.  Primary microcephaly is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.  In autosomal recessive inheritance, a non-working copy of the gene in each parent can cause the disorder.  Both parents must have one copy of the non-working gene in order for their child to have the disorder.  When both parents have one copy of the non-working gene, they have a 25% chance of having a child with the disorder with each pregnancy.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Balance disorders are not always curable. Depending on the cause of the disorder, it may be possible to reduce symptoms or prevent them from getting worse. 2. Treatment for balance disorders may include: physical therapy, medicines, surgery, changes in the home, and changes in the way a person moves. 3. The goal of treatment is to help people function as well as possible given their disorder. Treatment is based on a person's diagnosis. 4. People with balance problems often have fear of falling. This fear may cause them to limit their activities and to become more isolated. Working with a physical therapist can help people regain or improve their balance, coordination, and walking ability. 5. A physical therapist will create a customized exercise plan based on a person's diagnosis and ability. Exercises may include: balance board training, which uses a device with a platform that moves on a slant; balance retraining, which helps people learn to pay attention to their bodies and the environment while moving; and gait training, which helps people learn to walk safely and efficiently. 6. Medicines may help relieve symptoms of dizziness or nausea. People should talk to their doctor about possible side effects of medicines and medication interactions. 7. Surgery may be an option for people with certain balance disorders. Surgery may include: labyrinthectomy, which removes the inner ear; vestibular nerve section, which severs the nerve that sends balance information to the brain; or procedures to destroy or dampen the vestibular system, which may help relieve symptoms of dizziness and nausea. 8. Changes in the home can help people avoid falls and make it easier to move around. These changes may include: removing loose rugs or other tripping hazards; adding grab bars and raised edges in the bathroom; and improving lighting. 9. Changes in the way a person moves can also help improve balance and coordination. These changes may include: moving slowly, with small, slow steps; avoiding sudden head movements; and moving the feet in a wide base of support.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Your father may have a condition called benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). It is the most common cause of vertigo and is characterized by short periods of dizziness triggered by specific changes in the position of the head. 2. The condition is caused by the presence of small calcium crystals (canalizes) in the inner ear. The crystals can become dislodged and cause dizziness when they move in response to changes in the position of the head. 3. The goal of treatment is to move the crystals out of the inner ear so that they no longer cause vertigo. Movement exercises (such as the Brandt-Daroff exercises) may be recommended to help move the crystals out of the inner ear. Medications such as antihistamines or anticholinergics may also be used to help move the crystals out of the inner ear. 4. In severe cases, a procedure called a canalith repositioning procedure may be performed. During this procedure, the doctor moves the crystals out of the inner ear so that they no longer cause vertigo.
